Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Award: DMS-1105536
Principal Investigator: Guofang Wei

This proposal studies the geometry and topology of smooth metric
measure spaces with Bakry-Emery Ricci curvature bounded from
below and quasi-Einstein metrics. The Bakry-Emery Ricci
curvature is an important generalization of Ricci curvature for
smooth metric measure space, which occurs naturally as the
collapsed measured Gromov-Haudorff limit. Furthermore, the
Bakry-Emery Ricci curvature plays important roles in a variety of
topics such as the study of Ricci soliton, warped Einstein
metric, diffusion process, logrithmic Sobolev inequality, as well
as in the extension of Ricci curvature lower bound for metric
measure space. The principal investigator will study the geometry
of Ricci solitons; relation between comparison geometry and Ricci
flow and obtaining a combined estimate for the first eigenvalue
for Ricci positive and nonnegative lower bound. The PI will also
study the structures of the fundamental groups for manifolds with
lower integral Ricci curvature bound as well as minimal volume of
hyperbolic orbifolds.

Bakry-Emery Ricci curvature and Ricci soliton play a very
important role in Ricci flow, which led to the solution of
Poincare conjecture. Quasi-Einstein metrics is are important
both in mathematics and physics. Smooth metric measure space is
also related to optimal transport, information geometry, discrete
geometry. The proposed activities would have impact on all these
directions. The fundamental group is the most fundamental (as
the name implies) topological information. Its understanding will
greatly advance the study of the effect of curvature bounds on
the global topology of Riemannian manifolds, therefore will be
helpful in answering questions about the shape of the universe.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the award period 07/01/2011--6/31/2015, the PI published following seven papers:

1. Rigidity of Quasi-Einstein Metrics,  Diff. Geom. and Applications  29 (2011), 93-100 (joint with J. Case and  Y. Shu).

2.  On Volumes of hyperbolic orbifolds,
 Algebraic and Geometric Topology 12 (2012), 215-233 (joint with I. Adeboye).


3. Volume comparison and its generalizations, Advanced Lecture in Mathematics, Vol. 22 (2012) pp. 311-322.

4.  On Volume Growth of Gradient Steady Ricci Solitons, Pacific Journal of Math.  265-1 (2013), 233--241 (joint with P. Wu).

5.  On volumes of complex hyperbolic orbifolds, Michigan Math.  Journal  63, Issue 2 (2014), 355-369  (joint with I. Adeboye).


 6.  Various Covering Spectra for Complete Metric Spaces,  Asian Journal of Math 19, No. 1 (2015), 171-202  (joint with C. Sormani).


 7. Monotonicity Formulas for Bakry-Emery Ricci Curvature,   J. Geometric Analysis (2015),  (joint with B. Song, G. Wu).

These solves important problems in minimal volume,  Bakry -Emery Ricci curvature, Ricci solitons and covering spectrum, made essential contribution in quasi-Einstein metrics.

The PI has given over 20 research level talks in the award periods, including:  Ricci Solitons Days, Centro De Giorgi, Pisa (2011);Bay Area Differential Geometry Seminar, Stanford University (2011);  Mini-workshop on lower curvature bounds, Oberwolfach, Germany (2012);  Workshop in Optimal transportation and differential geometry, BIRS(2012); Workshop on Geometric Partial Differential Equations - Hsinchu Venue, Taiwan (2012);  AMS Plenary Lecture, Fall 2012 Meeting of the Western Section, U. of Arizona, Tucson, 10/12; Introductory Workshop on Optimal Transport: Geometry and Dynamics, MSRI (2013); Smoky-Cascade Geometry Conference, U. of Tennessee, Knoxville (2014), Cascade Topology Seminar, Oregon State University (2014). Workshop on Ricci curvature, Northwestern University (May 2015); Capital Normal University, Beijing, China (June 2015).  The PI  also gave a mini-course on "Comparison geometry for Bakry-Emery Ricci curvature" at National Center for Theoretical Science, Taiwan (2012).


The PI is actively involved in the graduate and undergraduate
programs in mathematics at the University of California (UCSB). In
the period, I have been the pure graduate advisor,  taught several topic courses in differential geometry; has designed and co-taught a NEW  introductory geometry and topology graduate class ``Fundamental Groups and Curvature"  with our RTG postdocotor Lee Kennard in the fall 2013 as part of RTG activities.
Four of my Ph.D. students graduated (Kevin Brighton (2012), Peng Wu (2012,co-chair), Brent Albrecht (2013),  Maree Jaramillo (2014).
 The PI supervised two senior theses (Henry Lankin, W,S2011; Jane Park, Summer 2014), a postdoctor from China (Bingyu Song, 2012-2013), and (co)-supervised our RTG post-doctor, Lee Kennard(2012-2015).    The PI  gave talks at UCSB undergraduate math club, UCSB math circle for high school students,  the graduate student colloquium, and the summer REU programm.
